Grab some beer and food and get excited

Welcome to Deep Learning in Action, 2nd Edition

Language: en

Welcome to our 2nd Edition. Introduction of Schedule and Sponsors. What is hot in the field of deep learning?

David Dao Student Researcher, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

ACM IEEE Computer Society

David is a M.Sc. Student at TUM and a student researcher in machine learning. Before his studies, David worked as intern at CERN. For his thesis he works on machine learning at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. He is interested in machine learning and its applications, including bioinformatics, computer vision, natural language processing and information retrieval

Case Study: Machine Learning in Fraud Detection

Language: en Complexity: Beginner

So far Machine Learning (ML) in business has mainly been used by 21st century companies like Google, Facebook, Amazon. Nowadays, business areas further away from the technological cutting edge become interested in profiting from the predictive power of ML algorithms and need external support to integrate them into their applications. In this areas, major points of implementing ML routines are data preparation in close collaboration with the client and subtle issues like the thread of automation and trust in complex technologies. TNG Technology Consulting offers high end IT-consulting for businesses in the Munich area, ranging from small innovative Start-Up’s to large telecommunication companies. Recently, we developed a ML based optimisation of a fraud detection system together with one of our clients. Our solution was a machine assisted human decision based on Support Vector Machines and Stochastic Neighbourhood embedding, which increased the fraud detection rate and let the client gain trust in the new technology.

Paul Pfeiffer Intern, TNG Technology Consulting

Paul Pfeiffer is a physicist by education, who entered into the IT-World via an internship at TNG Technology Consulting. During his physics studies in Konstanz and Munich, he has always been interested in information processing. Both his Bachelor and Master thesis were in the field of quantum information processing and during a research internship at the MPI of Neurobiology, he programmed artificial neural networks for the analysis of images from the brain.

System Identification and Forecasting with Recurrent Neural Networks

Language: en Complexity: Intermediate

Recurrent neural networks are an extreme example of deep learning models. We do not speak about a handful of layers but about hundreds of layers describing the system over time. As a guideline we will use a view which I have called ´Correspondence Principle´. This is a joint view between equations, architectures and local algorithms. We will start with general state space models, realize them as recurrent neural networks and move to more and more consistent descriptions of dynamical systems. At the end we will be able to handle models with several hundred thousands of neurons. Forecasting is not only an interesting application on the basis of system identification but also a test of the correctness of the model building. We have to accept, that our forecasts are not perfect and thus we will develop a method for the estimation of the forecast uncertainty.

Dr. Hans-Georg Zimmermann Principal Researcher, Siemens AG, Corporate Technology

Study of mathematics, computer science and operations research. Since 1987 at Siemens AG, Corporate Technology. 1988 founding member of the neural networks group in Siemens Munich. Scientific leader of the Learning Systems Group. Current research interests: System Identification, Forecasting and Control with Neural Networks. Applications in economics (time series analysis, forecasting, diagnosis, uncertainty analysis, and decision support) and engineering (process modeling, renewable energies, control and process surveillance).

Connectomics - The dense reconstruction of neural networks

Language: en Complexity: Beginner

The mapping of neuronal connectivity is one of the main challenges in neuroscience. Only with the knowledge of wiring diagrams is it possible to understand the computational capacities of neuronal networks, both in the sensory periphery, and especially in the mammalian cerebral cortex. Our methods for dense circuit mapping are based on 3-dimensional electron microscopy (EM) imaging of tissue, which allows imaging nerve tissue at nanometer-scale resolution across substantial volumes (typically hundreds of micrometers per spatial dimension) using Serial Block-Face Scanning Electron Microscopy (SBEM). The most time-consuming aspect of circuit mapping, however, is image analysis; analysis time far exceeds the time needed to acquire the data. Therefore, we developed methods to make circuit reconstruction feasible by increasing analysis speed and accuracy, using a combination of crowd sourcing and machine learning. We have applied these methods to circuits in the mouse retina, mapping the complete connectivity graph between almost a thousand neurons, and we are currently improving these methods for the application to neuronal circuits in the neocortex using automated image analysis, together with online science games.

Dr. Moritz Helmstaedter Director, Max Planck Institute for Brain Research

Born 1978 in Berlin, Germany. 1998 onwards studies of medicine and physics at Ruprecht-Karls-University Heidelberg, Germany (Medical license and Diploma in physics). Brief interlude as strategy consultant with McKinsey. Doctoral thesis with Bert Sakmann and Post-Doc with Winfried Denk at the Max Planck Institute for Medical Research in Heidelberg. 2011-2014 Research Group leader and Principal Investigator at the Max Planck Institute of Neurobiology, Munich. Since August 2014 Director and Scientific Member at the Max Planck Institute for Brain Research. For his research activities, Moritz Helmstaedter was honored with the Otto Hahn Medal and the Bernard Katz Lecture.
